Definition: In this task, you will receive a public comment from online platforms. You are expected to divide the comment into two classes: threat and non-threat. A threat is the statement that someone will be hurt or harmed, especially if the person does not do something specific.

Positive Examples.input: Comment: He should be executed, not given 48 years.
Positive Examples.explanation: This comment conveys a violent threat to someone.

Positive Examples.input: Comment: Opening up people of a different race to violent acts including death by idiots, by inciting her followers to violence, is offensive. If anything happens to the Jones family, Dembroski should be charged as an accessory.
Positive Examples.explanation: This comment might be toxic but is not a threat to anyone.

Comment: He got his money... now he lies in wait till after the election in 2 yrs.... dirty politicians need to be afraid of Tar and feathers again... but they aren't and so the people get screwed.
Negative Examples.explanation: This comment is clearly unrelated to threat.

Comment: Just to correct a factual error: the US no longer has 10 times the population of Canada (which those of us who are old enough remember it being for decades). Due to differences in growth, largely related to immigration, the US only has 9 times the population (316.5 M vs. 35.16 M as of 2013, 322.8 M vs. 36.3 M as of 2016, dropping from 9x to 8.9x over 3 years), and under the current US administration that difference in growth is only likely to accelerate. Given the factors that other commentators here have mentioned, and the new EU deal (EU-28 pop. 510.1 M in 2016), while Canada may not have blunt leverage as the article suggests, our vulnerability in a trade war with the US is diminishing over time. The Liberal gov't should be hedging their bets that way even as they avoid poking the US admin. in the eye.

Comment: Ballot initiatives mean diddly squat, AKfox.  In 2002, well over 60% of voters approved the initiative to build the gasline and we even created an oil and gas commission.  The commission is hauling in millions in income, but it's 14 years later and we still don't have a gasline because Big Oil and the Republican majority are blocking the 14-year-old initiative without a fight from the voters.

Secondly, voters also passed a ballot measure to tax the cruise ship passengers a $50 head tax, but when Parnell was voted into office, and in the first six months, he flew to Florida and met with the cruise ship CEOs and pledge to not only roll back the head tax, but water down Alaska's Clean Water legislation.  Apparently governors can do what they want with citizens' initiatives without a voter fight.  And don't forget that it was the Republican majority that passed legislation years ago upping the ante on making it more difficult for voters to collect signatures.

Comment: David Brown 980. The Gathering Place not only provides a lunch program and food bank. People there work to change policies to fight for human and civil rights. The Gathering Place provides showers and a place to nap for people who have no place to stay at night. The Gathering Place is once of very few places where women, transgender, and children can go to actually be safe. It's not a perfect place, but much of what is there is a perfect example of what humanity should be like: Caring and acceptance.  It's a place where the people who go there talk to each other and help find answers by sharing their own resources, like change for the bus, like a place to stay for a few weeks, like a friend to talk to, like a couch in an apartment to rest in for a couple of weeks, like a place to share writing, music, and art.

Comment: I think you got that view from another G&M opinion piece I remember reading which, once again, wasn’t based on fact. Pipeline companies charge tolls to ship oil or gas and those tolls are mandated by the national regulator. Doesn’t have anything to do with the price of oil (so much for your Econ 101 tutorial). Here’s some more basic economics and energy knowledge for you, when Eastern Canada imports oil via ship (tidewater) that oil is based off Brent pricing. Brent oil currently trades at a ~$7 premium to WTI. Canadian oil is landlocked due to lack of infrastructure thus trades off WTI. So we sell our oil at a discount to WTI which trades at a discount to Brent because we can’t figure out how to build a pipeline. And Eastern Canada gets screwed with higher gasoline prices because they have to import more expensive oil priced off Brent. Educate yourself on the facts vs taking G&M opionion pieces at face value.

Comment: I call BS on the veteran dying dan. I get excellent healthcare from the VA and you won't hear many vets complaining.  Here's the estimate from the CBO.

" Immediately 14 million would lose insurance just in the individual market.
Later, following additional changes to subsidies for insurance purchased in the nongroup market and to the Medicaid program, the increase in the number of uninsured people relative to the number under current law would rise to 21 million in 2020 and then to 24 million in 2026. The reductions in insurance coverage between 2018 and 2026 would stem in large part from changes in Medicaid enrollment—because some states would discontinue their expansion of eligibility, some states that would have expanded eligibility in the future would choose not to do so, and per-enrollee spending in the program would be capped. In 2026, an estimated 52 million people would be uninsured, compared with 28 million who would lack insurance that year under current law."

Comment: oldclerk
For the record
The Normal Actuarial Cost for the public service plan in 1980 was 16.2% of salary. That was what was needed to pay for the pensions.

Employees were told that 6 and one half % of their salary went to pension, matched by government as employer. Plus 1% of salary for indexing, matched by government as employer. Total 15%. 

So it seems that total compensation was take home pay before taxes plus 16.2% of salary plus other benefits.

Comment: Isn't passive investment income earned in a corporation subject to Part IV tax (dividends) and other high rate taxes (i.e. there is no small business deduction for investment income)?  In effect, in Alberta for example, the initial corporate tax rate is 50.67% on passive investment income (interest, dividends, rent, royalties) as compared to a 48% highest marginal personal tax rate on investment income (for income earners over $300,000 of income).  Therefore, this article, and other people (govt and tax advisors) are not really giving the full picture here.  
There are two issues.  Shareholders get taxed at small business rate 12% in Alberta.  If they take out the money as dividends, they are taxed at 48% altogether.  There is a 36% deferral, money that can be left in the company to compound.  In the end, CRA will get more money, it is just deferred.  The other issue is some business owners may be treating passive investment income as business income (incorrect tax filing).  Thoughts?

Comment: Charles, I think it's far too late. If the world stopped burning fossil fuels today, the planet would continue to heat to a catastrophic level, possibly at the expense of most life on Earth. That's no excuse for not trying to do as much as we can, because doing the right thing for its own sake is good enough, and you are correct, it is a moral issue. 

I've been following this subject for years, and humans have set in motion forces that we will not be able to undo, in the same way that we have no answers for the ongoing Fukushima disaster, which continues to dump 300 to 400 tons of radioactive water into the Pacific every day. In the 60s, when nuclear energy was unleashed on the world, engineers didn't have permanent answers for the radioactive waste. They assured everyone that by the time those spent fuel rods were a problem, engineers would find an answer. They haven't, and spent fuel rods and deteriorating storage is now a multi-thousand year problem.  Human hubris is a problem.

Comment: The essay by Spadaro and Figueroa raises an interesting question: how does one change public opinion in our Church? In 2015, Pope Francis spoke to Congress and, through them, to the American people.  He spoke of great Americans -- Lincoln, Day, Merton, King. In 2016, we elected Mr. Trump. 
In 2014 and 2015, Pope Francis gathered the bishops of the world into a synod to discuss the family, then wrote an Apostolic Exhortation, Amoris Laetitia, to focus our ideas and energies on divine mercy. But the divisions among us appear to grow deeper. 
I think Pope Francis has tried everything he knows to bring about change, but we and our world have become so resistant to everything but what we want to hear, it all falls on deaf ears. Being deaf, I know how that feels. Until someone comes along who can give us a new language, a way of signing perhaps, that can replace the old ways of speaking to ourselves, I don't see how any of this will change.

Comment: " Plus all the investment income you earn in the RRSP/RRIF will be taxed on withdrawal."
This is not correct and a commonly misunderstood aspect of RRSPs. The part of the RRSP contribution that you own (as opposed to the part the government owns, the amount depending on your tax rate) is never taxed - the growth and when removed from your RRSP. Just the same as your TFSA. The part the government owns - all the original capital and the growth of it is returned to the government when money is withdrawn from your RRSP. Hence if you are in a 50% tax bracket when you withdraw any money - half of it goes to the government. More detail on this here:

http://retailinvestor.org/RRSPmodel.html

Another error in the answer - the gentleman stated he is retired. He therefore has no earned income. Therefore he will not get a tax deduction if he contributes to his RRSP.

Comment: Paul:  Let's start here:  The term in loco parentis, Latin for "in the place of a parent" refers to the legal responsibility of a person or organization to take on some of the functions and responsibilities of a parent. Originally derived from English common law, it is applied in two separate areas of the law."  The in loco parentis role for colleges and universities has receded markedly over the last few decades.  First, of course, most students are at least 18 years old, many are 21 and both groups are, in legal terms, "adults."  These young men and women are out of their homes, out from under direct parental supervision and, putting it mildly, disinclined to have the university assume that supervisorial role.  Additionally, universities are less than excited about becoming the "parents" to thousands of young men and women (can you blame them?)
  (cont)

Comment: Seat damage can often occur when a valve is first lifted as part of the general plant commissioning procedure, because very often, dirt and debris are present in the system. To ensure that foreign matter does not pass through the valve, the system should be flushed out before the safety valve is installed and the valve must be mounted where dirt, scale and debris cannot collect. Feel free to verify this act by going to any of the major valve manufacturer websites such as Spirax Sarco or Kunkle. As I stated in a previous post, steam hammering is a very common occurrence that can occur at anytime and any pressure, due to even a minor equipment failure. It doesn't automatically equate to human error. And if the operators were in fact in the process of flushing the system, and following the valve manufacturer's instructions, what grievous crime was committed?

Comment: Part 1: In a sea of orange and blue, the excitement pierced the atmosphere at Sports Authority Field. This was a defining game for the Denver Broncos. The Dallas Cowboys were expected to destroy the newly rebuilt Denver Broncos team. I had three expectations for this game: Denver needed to stop the run, score on offense, and have few turnovers. My first expectation was that the Denver Broncos defense needed to hold the Cowboys’ run game to minimal yardage. The Denver Broncos defensive players haven’t defended the run game well in previous years, which made this one of the most important goals for the team in this game. My second expectation was that the Denver Broncos needed to score using offensive players in order to provide their defensive players with a well-deserved rest.

Comment: Aloha Narissa,

I am sure you mean well.  However, please understand that expanding the monument is not as simple as has been presented by its advocates, and it will significantly affect local people.  Especially small-scale fishermen on Kauai who depend on the area for bottomfish and ahi. This could potentially destroy some peoples' livelihoods, including Hawaiians.  Nor is the science a "no-brainer".  There is a long history of management and data collection within the US EEZ by NOAA.  Much of this does not support the idea that closing the entire area to Hawaii-based fishing vessels will serve the interests of conservation.  As a fisherman I firmly believe that our future lies in science-based management, not arbitrary ocean closures.

This is a complex issue, and I would encourage you to take the time to speak with and listen to those who will be affected by the President's decision before endorsing this proposal wholeheartedly.  Is this something you'd be interested in doing?

Comment: Just a quick note for non economists. The trade deficit translates to cash outflow, which is the current account deficit that has people so concerned.

Foreign investment leads to jobs and economic growth. Trump does not understand international trade or macro economics. But neither does Bannon or a lot of people apparently.

Comment: There were two rules at play here, the rule for cloture and the rule for approval.
The rule for approval was a simple majority.  This was NOT changed, and the judge was approved by this existing rule.
The rule that was changed was the cloture rule.
The established rule to change a rule was applied to the rule for cloture, not the rule for approval.
*

Comment: You couldn't be more wrong. Actually, building up is far more cost-effective, utility-wise. Comment: Many departments require their officers to purchase their duty guns so yours is a false equivalency.  Body cam programs are expensive so where does this money come from? This can cost small departments tens of thousands of dollars a year and for large departments like Denver or Aurora the cost could easily be in the hundreds of thousands maybe more.

Comment: We need regulations in place to protect the American public from monopolies on pharmaceuticals. It doesn't matter which party does it or who we blame for the mess. Pharmaceuticals have in-elastic demand which means price has little effect on if patients buy or don't buy. In such situations, the market is ineffective in setting prices and regulation is necessary. The alternative is the current situations with premiums so high that people can't afford insurance for routine health care. The high prices are a result of how the market works--or doesn't work--not the result of any one person's greed.

Comment: _"Renting those apartments at fair market prices could generate about $961,000 each year, while renting them out to people who make 60 percent of the area median income would only produce about $380,000 per year, he said"_

FYI, rent that is 30% of 60% of AMI is a reasonable reference point for "affordable" "workforce housing" in Eugene.

This is the reference point (or something close to it) that the City should be using for the requirement in the revised MUPTE ordinance that requires 30% of the units in a project approved for MUPTE to be "workforce housing."

Instead, the City Manager and Mayor had the City Attorney slip in "30% of 100% of AMI" as the reference point at the last minute.

That means the threshold was set somewhere around 1.66 times as high as it should have been and therefore the MUPTE "workforce housing" requiement is virtually meaningless.

This by our "progressive" Mayor!

-- Paul

Comment: I don't think the guilt trip is necessary in this case.  There was a prior commitment that had to be honoured.  When we say we are going to pick up our kids, I would hope that that they would be able to depend on that, short of an unavoidable  delay.   It took me years but I eventually came to realize that I couldn't please everyone who approaches me.  If I am free, then I am glad to help, but if I have to be somewhere else, or take time to do something that I have promised to someone else, then I must say no, unless it is a matter of life and death, which it generally isn't.   Prioritizing the commitment I already have ensures that I don't let someone else down.

Comment: I am reminded of the old real estate saying that the two best ways of destroying a city are 1) the introduction of rent controls 2) an artillery barrage.

We have seen this sort of populism before when rent controls were first introduced thirty or so years ago.  The effect was to virtually stop the construction of new purpose built rental buildings.  As I recall there was a comparison done that showed that Montreal built 10,000 new purpose built rental units in one particular year and Toronto built about 300.  The 1991 exemption was an attempt to induce builders to re-start the construction of rental units.  Essentially the government gave their word that these units would never be subject to rent control.  Ms Wynne has just broken that moral contract and in fact may have broken a legal contract.  I expect that this will end up in court.

Comment: It's not easy, and shouldn't be given how many rights are involved (we are essentially talking about incarcerating someone and infringing on other fundamental rights), but it can work if anyone cares to at least start the process.

One thing to keep in mind, it's easy to think about this case in isolation, but any loosening of the procedure opens it up to abuse by an authoritarian government. 

Not to go too "tin foil" but it is intellectually inconsistent (and more than a bit hypocritical) to worry about any given administration, like the current one, being an extrajudicial threat to the civil rights of their opponents, then hand them the power to arbitrarily declare people "insane," without legal recourse, and incarcerate them just because you have a problem with one single such right.

Again not going Godwin nor Stalin-ing, but we have real, fairly recent experience with that sort of thing. If people truly fear the current admin they can't logically make this one case an exception.

Comment: Why do you assume that the 88% has to be "countered?" This retrospective study  looked at 139 male patients of whom 122 resolved their gender issues and 17 went on to identity as transgender.   Zucker's  clinic treated over a thousand young patients during his tenure. If we accept the robustness of the data and variable controls, your query seems to suggest that some portion of the 88% would somehow switch teams with a different approach than Zucker's? That the fraction itself is a product OF his approach? You see the problem with this faulty logic, no? That is an untestable question for obvious ethical  reasons.  Sadly, that doesn't prevent histrionic speculation. But, there is something we DO know. The 17 young males who WERE treated with Zucker's non-affirming approach but still identify as TG (the kind of TG person Wente concedes really must be TG) underwent a treatment antithetical to their true identity. That's not speculation - just a fact.

Comment: The Globe and Mail, and indeed most/all of the news sites, do this every single quarter that Stats. Can. releases such a report.  There are dozens of pieces of data in this quarterly report but the G&M only ever reports on one piece and takes the most dim view of it.

The 'household debt service ratio' bit is an important piece of this puzzle and really explains WHY household debt is increasing: People are able to afford it better.  As much as the doom and gloom crowd keep claiming that the end is nigh people are actually spending near record-low amounts to maintain that debt, which kind of flies in the face of the notion that some massive implosion is imminent.

Certainly a lot could change IF interest rates go up by any significant amount, but I don't think anyone should hold their breath for that one.

Comment: The problem is there IS value in having jobs with different benefit packages not just 100% salary now.   People are making decisions off of the now and 'guaranteed' futures of what is offered for a job.   They clearly don't value future 'guarantees' from companies largely because they have shown the guarantees are no good.   With government there is no reason why the guarantee shouldn't be good.   And budgetwise it makes sense too.  Hire person x plan on paying his salary to 'death' all while the value of that salary declines or at best stays stable.   From a budgeting perspective that is easy.   Changing everything to a new structure to try and match the private sector is hard.   That comes with HUGE upfront costs and larger ongoing costs.   

Unlike businesses that could dissolve and drop those costs government can't do that (without severe consequences that is).  We could fund it through cutting some programs I guess. Though the only ones big enough to matter are SS and Medicare/aid

Comment: My perpetual answer to statements such as Mr. Flanagan's "...disbar parties from making definite-sounding campaign promises..." is to refer to the Ontario Superior Court of Justice ruling on the Canadian Taxpayer's Federation v. The Government of Ontario regarding Dalton McGuity's written promise not to raise taxes if elected.  You can get it here:  http://www.taxpayer.com/media/73.pdf

In short, the Court ruled that no one may be held to a pre-election promise should they eventually form government.  Something about a concept of not thwarting the will of Parliament.

So, thank you Dalton, thank you so very much for bringing out in the open and making it official that ANYTHING said by an aspiring politician during an election campaign has NO LEGAL FORCE, let alone moral obligation.  I would urge every Canadian voter to remember this whenever an election comes nigh.

Comment: Ah Yes. The accounting in you versus finance manager in me. You are right in net totals. But in order for us to use sources and uses tables, we need to see all funding sources, not net, because we do use these things to manage forward resources. So depending on timing we could have all the debt outstanding and we'd have to scramble around for funding. Presume there are financial covenants that we watch, or some other trigger like capital adequacy, or partners we have to make capital calls from. Very handy to use if you know how to incorporate the information into management practice. But that means we have to keep cumulative debt in these tables. And also from a practical standpoint, if I go before a board asking for money, I really don't want to be caught by a surprise question saying why a debt facility wasn't included. The last thing I want to do is explain discrepancies.

Comment: Andi, for once I have to disagree with you. On occasion we get blindsided by our experiences, conventional wisdom and perceptions. This is one of them. And I can tell you, we are so fortunate to have her working for us.  Our trails are being restored  for the first time in decades, several for the first time since construction.  The Chester Creek Trail is her finest work yet.  She probably got tagged to talk to the press and has a fine line to walk as anyone in that position would.  I would also urge folks to compare our trails to say, those in many other major cities. The level of vandalism and graffiti is far less and for that Parks and Rec is due a lot of credit for forging and managing successful partnerships.

Comment: Your outhouse is 1 holer?

Back in the 1960s a horse drawn "honey wagon" still used to make the rounds in High River Alberta. Most of the outhouses in town had at least 2 seats, more often at least 2 on the male side and another 2 for the female side, with no partitions except between the male and female sides of the outhouses.

A CBC drama about post WW I troops being kept in service after the Armistice, to send to Russia against the communists, had a realistic portrayal of troops sitting around in a real military latrine of the era, talking to each other while seated on the "thrones" with no partitions around the openings.

Comment: The NAFTA renegotiation struggle between Canada & Mexico, on the one hand, & the Trump Administration, on the other, has been to (a) control the substance, nature & tone of the negotiation agenda, & (b) advance the economic & public policy objectives if their own countries respectively through that control.

Canada & Mexico have so far, given that they are the smaller players with the most to lose if negotiations fail,  done surprisingly well by (a) assembling strong research, diplomatic & negotiating teams that have placed useful reform proposals forward for negotiation & presentation (together with some proposals designed to be sacrificed during negotiations) to potential US domestic allies, & (b) maintained a positive but resolute tone so as to deprive the Trump Administration of a pretext to throw negotiations into crisis.

Comment: Hawaii's Curfew Law: A juvenile 15-years-old or younger out in public, must have adult supervision between the hours of 10 p.m. to 4 a.m.
There are exceptions however, and that’s if a Family Court judge permits it, or if the child is on the street for necessity, like returning home their job or school functions.
Officers can call the child’s parents or guardians to make sure they know what is going on.
If a child is in a public place without an adult during the curfew hours, an officer can make an arrest, so it’s important that parents who have children this age, know where their child is at night.

Comment: RRIF removals are "pension income" and a "minimum" amount based on age must be taken out annually.  The author is presenting a case where before age 71 an individual is probably planning to take more out annually than the formula would dictate because one is looking at minimizing income tax whether that is now, later or over the long run!  As soon as one is eligible for "pension income" splitting and particularly if one's spouse's income is much less, there is significant tax saving available if one can report/shift taxable income from the one with a higher bracket to space available in the other's lower bracket!  If one doesn't need the funds put them into both spouses TFSAs where they are tax free "forever".

A RRIF with the spouse named as "successor annuitant" allows RRIF payments to flow to the surviving spouse without interruption, potentially minimizing or negating estate administration and taxes!

$74,788 x 2=$149,576 income for a retired couple before any OAS is lost after 65!

Comment: Trade deals may have gone too far and grown too be too complex. But let us not forget that the mother of multi-national trade deals, the European Coal and Steel Community (ECSC), was formed in years following WW2.  The objective was to remove these two key industries from control by nationalistic politics by submitting them to multi-national regulations, and with that to reduce the risk of international industrial disputes from exploding into military wars. The  ECSC was the seed from which the EU emerged. 
One need only compare the first half to the second have of the 20th century in Europe to recognize that this multinational economic deal achieved what it was designed to achieve.

We should think about that before going back to championing economic nationalism.

But because I've been to Mass that day, because I scattered prayers from the Rosary about during my day, becuase God hasn't been very far from my mind during the day...instead of saying "No,  I'll do it tomorrow...I want to drink my beer & read my book"...instead I say "let's do it..go get the hair cutting kit"....and my son smiles..and my wife smiles..and I smile..and all my other kids "get a sense" of a more generous type of response that we can give to each other.

Comment: This isn't about whether climate change is real, but about whether these hurricanes are a symptom of climate change (they are not), and whether hurricane frequency or intensity is rising (they are not). 

Cliff Mass, Phillip Klotzbach, and the NOAA are not "deniers", and form a major oart of my argument, so I'm not cherry-picking. Besides, dismissing data or opinion just because of who said it is argumentum ad hominem. 

Flood damage is not a reliable  indicator of hurricane severity or climate change. The insured value of assets in flood-prone areas has been rising sharply for a century. In fact, because private insurers didn't want to insure such properties, government stepped in with flood insurance which encourages building in flood-prone area. People prefer to build their houses along water frontage instead of on higher ground, because they know the government will bail them out if disaster does strike.

Comment: If you think putting Alaska Natives in charge of ANY natural resource will provide any degree of protection or conservation, you apparently do not read much. You can watch fifteen or twenty boats go out there every morning and spend the day killing ducks and geese even though it is totally illegal and unethical, until their boats are literally full, then coming back to town, taking a dozen or two home for supper, coming back the next day, dumping the other hundred or so dead birds out of the boat and going back out to blast a couple hundred more. Yep, they are definitely "Stewards of the Land" alright. Or go do a census of game within 30 miles of ANY village in NW or SW Alaska. No moose, no caribou. If it moves, kill it. If it flies it dies.

Comment: "...shut it down and die."

Most Catholics don't even know what the Curia is, much less know who is in that institution or group; but you want it dismantled. Maybe replace it with global representatives from the 150 or so National Conferences of Bishops representing 1.2 billion Catholics? I don't know. I haven't the answer except that it will take a long time to dismantle the Curia -- to make the unrigging successful. Bishops can do it by asserting themselves as individual national bodies, but that seems unlikely right now. Some National Conferences of Bishops, of course, are more progressive than others. In the meantime, in dealing with abuse in churches (and everywhere, really), the best route (for bringing about reform) seems to be through local civil courts, sympathetic laypeople and clerics, the press, and Pope Francis. If courts jailed a few bishops, that might help a lot, too.

Comment: I believe you are confusing "Natural Law" and (some form of) "Law of Nature."  The moral concept of "Natural Law" is not based on the observation of nature and trying to derive law by deduction.  It is based on the idea that humans are rational creatures, by nature, and therefore should act based on that nature.  It's sum is "Do good and avoid evil," with the concept of "evil" being far more broad in definition than a synonym for "bad."

Comment: FYI, Toronto composting system does NOT recommend using biodegradable bags to line the compost buckets/bins. I find that the biodegradable bags start to compost in my small compost bucket and make a horrible mess. I usually have a couple of random shopping bags that I use instead.
The following is from the city of Toronto website:

"There is no need to buy special bags; used grocery bags are fine. Using a bio-degradable bag does not provide any real benefit. The mechanism used to open and separate the bags full of organics cannot distinguish a compostable/bio-degradable plastic bag from a regular plastic bag. All bags are opened, removed and treated as residue that requires landfill disposal."

Comment: Money laundering

INTERPOL's definition of money laundering is: "any act or attempted act to conceal or disguise the identity of illegally obtained proceeds so that they appear to have originated from legitimate sources".
Illegally obtained funds are laundered and moved around the globe using and abusing shell companies, intermediaries and money transmitters. In this way, the illegal funds remain hidden and are integrated into legal business and into the legal economy.
At INTERPOL, we work to combat money laundering through the global exchange of data, supporting operations in the field, and bringing together experts from the variety of sectors concerned. We work closely with other international organizations to foster international awareness of the importance of using financial investigative techniques against organized criminal activities and to avoid duplication of effort.

Comment: No one said we shouldn't have roads. 
Just that we should prioritize pedestrians, transit, and biking above private cars in funding and design of our public space. 
Currently we prioritize car traffic far above all else, making all other means of getting around extremely difficult. 
Continuing to do this is not sustainable. There is not and will never be enough money and space for everyone to drive. We have to invest our limited transportation funds in modes that are more energy and space efficient, and that are financially sustainable. That means putting money into bike and pedestrian infrastructure. That means not only allowing buses to use the roads, but dedicating them space so that they can function efficiently and actually be useful to people. 

I did not say to build special roads for commercial vehicles. I was placing them within a hierarchy of priorities, and suggesting that the gas tax they pay needs to be raised.

Comment: Odd that Bill Curry gives as his example of a PBO study prompted by a request from an Opposition MP the F-35 costing without mentioning the update of the Budget 2015 fiscal outlook that the PBO did in July 2015 at the request of Liberal MP Scott Brison and NDP MP Nathan Cullen. This study was, after all, by his own admission, the road to Damascus moment for Justin Trudeau that suddenly turned him from a leader who would balance every budget to someone promising to run “modest deficits for three years”. The PBO was requested to update the budget estimates for the Bank of Canada’s real GDP projections; otherwise it made only tiny adjustments to the DOF forecast. This turned a $1.5B surplus forecast for 2015-16 into a $1.0B deficit forecast. Trudeau took its projection of a deficit as if it were the word of God, although it wasn’t even the PBO’s best estimate, but only a constrained estimate following specifications from the Liberal and NDP Finance critics.

Comment: Here's a different perspective. My parents owned a mortgaged home and raised my brother and I. We had lots of love and our quality of life was great. My father worked hard and got dirty at work. my mother stayed at home except when she did things with us after school. 

However, there was one car, 2 bedrooms, a winter of skating, hockey, road hockey and company to chat and play cards. Summer was sandlot ball, bike hikes, swimming in the river (no municipal pool ), picnics, tenting on a stream with the farmer's approval, visiting relatives nearby, family reunions, and other stuff.  My father even found the money to take us to a cottage one week every summer.  His secret was it's not what you make, but what you spend. Even more important, what you spend it on! 

Ok everyone, pile on.

Comment: Today is April 4, which is a bit early for everything but feeder kings. The first herring begin showing up very soon, followed by halibut. Optimistic Deep Creek salmon and halibut anglers will start heading out in a few weeks, and the charter boats begin booking in May when the action starts heating up.  Beluga follow the herring and hooligan.

It would be more accurate to say that we're a few weeks away from significant numbers of salmon or whales, but since the vast majority of oil spilled today will still be in the East and West rips then, you can hardly describe that as "really reaching."

Comment: On another occasion, I attended a book signing for the science fiction writer David Weber. After he gave his (very interesting) talk, I asked him to do me a favor. In some of his Honor Harrington books, he has a major character named "Rob S. Pierre," and I asked him not to do anything like that again. He said that he thought it was clever when he did it, but agreed it was a bad joke and promised he wouldn't do it again. A young woman asked, "What was the joke?"

Weber said, "It's a play on the name 'Robespierre'."

"Who's Robespierre?"

"One of the movers and shakers of the French Revolution."

"What's the French Revolution?" Everyone else there just looked at her, and we all apparently decided it wasn't worth trying to explain one of the major events of history to her.

Comment: At all incidents, the IC uses the National Incident Management System, Incident Command System (NIMS ICS), to develop his Incident Action Plan (IAP).  The ICS provides a framework that allows the IC to rapidly scale up or retract, as the incident changes.  An important concept is that the ICS does NOT recognize the rank of an individual in his day job.  It recognizes qualifications. The positions in the ICS are given to persons that are qualified to accomplish the objectives.  Thus, a Captain, or even the lowest Fire Fighter 1, can hold the position of a Section Chief at an incident if he is qualified, and conversely, a Chief Officer can hold a lower position under that Section Chief at the same incident.  This is why F1, F2, F4, & F5 did not take command.  The BC at the scene already had his key players in place to attain his objectives.  To throw a new IC in his place, in the middle of the incident, would be counterproductive. Their presence was to support the IC.

Comment: I couldn't get past the sentence declaring the drive time from London to Toronto to be 2 hours.  On what day of the week and what hour of the day would this be happening?  Certainly not during rush hour or construction season.  High speed rail would circumvent the traffic which makes that "2 hour" drive more along the lines of 3 plus hours on a good day.  Furthermore, doing business in Toronto isn't just about commuting into an office tower daily. It isn't just about "jobs".  Many people do much of their work on line and require some face to face meetings each week.  High speed rail would facilitate the new world of work, and help people strike a work/life balance, while being able to live in truly livable communities.  You know, ones where the notion of having more than a tiny balcony to access the great out of doors isn't a pipe dream, and does actually cost less than 7 figures.  As for private versus government, I'll go back now that I have that out of my system. :-)

Comment: Globe editorial: "How to pop Toronto’s housing bubble, without blowing up the economy"

The headline should be "How NOT to pop Toronto's housing bubble ...", because that's all the editorial offers. The writers give plenty advice on what not to do, and exhortations to act "boldly but thoughtfully", with no indication what that could mean.

One step in the right direction would be enforcement of existing laws about capital gains, tax on new constructions, money laundering, etc. Beyond that, tightening mortgage rules would help some. But once you are in a bubble, there is no easy way to take the air out of it "boldly but thoughtfully".

Comment: That is not correct. MTR is a public/private corporation. Only 23% of its shares were sold to private shareholders. Of course it is run for profit. It should be. Its Board is made up of representatives from business, the civil community and the State. Whether the HK Authority subsidises the tickets, or use some other form of cross-subsidy, I don't know. It is a huge international corporation and runs national & international rail links as well as the inner city light rail routes, develops properties, etc. etc. But it stands to reason that in the kind of society that exists there, ie poor Chinese, thousands of foreigners and rich banker types, (all of whom use the service btw) some form of subsidy will be used.  

The primary difference between MTR and Transnet is efficiency. Your position regarding subsidies is based on prejudice, and you are quite prepared to throw the baby out with the bathwater because of it.

Comment: If the 6% IAP Contribution is directed to the Pension plan, and if the collective bargaining language requires the employer to provide a 6% pay increase.  Making this change would actually cost more than the current plan.

For example, if an employee is currently paid $1,000 a month the employer send $76.50 (7.65%) to FICA, about $220 (22%) to PERs pension and $60 (6%) to the IAP, so the employee costs the employer $1,357 for the month.  If the IAP contribution is redirected and the employee has to provide a 6% pay increase, the employee's month pay becomes $1,060, $81 (7.65%) goes to FICA, $297 (28%) goes to PERS pension, $0 goes to the IAP and the employee now costs the employer $1,438 for the month, an increase of $81.

Unless the employer's resource have increased, this change results in less services being able to be provided by the employer.

Comment: The only diet that will reverse cardiovascular disease is a whole food, plant-based diet that is low in fat - No oil! Not even olive oil!*. Studies conducted have the same result. The people who stick to such a diet reverse their heart disease and live well into old age. The people who don't do the diet, suffer with cardiac "events" and in most cases die years before they should. 

*Short term studies on olive oil showed benefits, but the long term studies (5 years or longer) showed that consumption of olive oil resulted in the same damage to coronary arteries as eating meat. It's the fat that is the problem.

Carbohydrates, as long as they're whole food, complex carbs like potatoes, intact grains, squashes, vegetables, and fruits, will never contribute to heart disease and diabetes. In the case of type 2 diabetes, insulin resistance is caused by a diet high in fats, especially animal fats. By eating a low fat plant-based diet, diabetes is reversed. It's the fats, not the complex carbs

Comment: Haven't read all of your many comments on the subject (I work for a living) but what's clear from those I have read is your refusal to consider that those voting against rezoning could be motivated by anything but bias. 

As to what constitutes evidence, I regret to disappoint you; I do indeed have a reasonable grasp of the rules of evidence in Canada's courts. The mayor's comments fall into the category of hearsay. Without corroboration, they have no probative value. Similarly, any testimony regarding the activities of an advocacy group would be rejected absent proof as to its actual - not speculative - impact on voters. Unless you plan to abrogate the sanctity of the ballot box and force voters to testify why they voted the way they did, I see little possibility of your challenge making it to trial - let alone prevailing on its merits.

Comment: A very interesting article, clearly laying out the views of some of the folks who oppose the TMT. But I find the term "Haole science" rather odd. Does this mean that science as practiced by, say, Japanese or Pakistanis or Egyptians or South Africans is somehow an ethnic enterprise? Does it mean that an Englishman's discovery of penicillin or the discovery of the cause and modern treatment of the Black Plague by a scientist in Viet Nam should not be applied to Native Hawaiians who are suffering from terrible diseases? Or is this an essentialized view of life in which there is no common humanity? Is this any different than some true believers in faiths such as Christian Science who allow their sick children to suffer without "Haole science" medical attention? One can respect the views presented by people who oppose TMT, but not the racialization of such important issues. Let us discuss these matters with civility in Civil Beat.

Comment: There is an enormous backstory here that is vitally important​.

I know Fr. Gerry McBrearity from my seminary days at St. Mary's Seminary & University in Baltimore.  Theological College (TC) at CUA is a Sulpician seminary.  Just last year and due to the overreach of San Francisco Archbishop Sal Cordileone, the Sulpicians were discharged from St. Patrick's Seminary & University at Menlo Park, CA after leading the seminary for 118 years.  They officially left at the end of the May 2017 academic year.   Cordileone ran them out.  See the related NCR article: https://www.ncronline.org/news/people/sulpicians-withdraw-san-francisco-seminary

I am certain that McBrearity, TC, and the Sulpicians did not want the same thing to happen at CUA.  They caved.

In the age of Francis, this is so tragic.  The more things change, the more they stay the same.  I don't see how the Roman Catholic Church in the U.S. and Europe is not on a collision course.

Gerry, where the Sulpician prophetic voice?

Comment: Yes, it was a better report than the Bank of Canada expected but the bottom line is still that growth under the Trudeau regime has been anemic. Even with the upward revisions to 2016Q1 and 2016Q2 growth rates the annual growth rate for 2016Q3 was 1.3%, which is simply pathetic from a leader who promised us much stronger growth than under Harper and is spending like a drunken sailor allegedly to achieve it. Dave now wonders if the 1.5% growth forecast for 2016Q4 isn’t much too pessimistic. Could be, but I’m not sure why he would think so. The Trudeau regime hasn’t strung together two quarters of solid growth yet: 2015Q4 was almost flat, and 2016Q2, even after revision, still registers the strongest quarterly drop in output since 2009Q2.

However...
"The price for detached houses sold in the Fraser Valley board’s territory averaged $914,763 last month, up 1.2 per cent from November and 13.7 per cent from December, 2015."  The "average" is quite misleading. 

In Chilliwack, you can purchase a pretty decent home for under $400,000--Royal LePage features over 8 pages of them in that price category--ranchers, older homes, townhouses and condos.  Travel west just 25 minutes closer to Vancouver, and the picture changes significantly.  You'll scarcely find a detached home in Abbotsford for under $400,000. Royal Lepage offers dozens of homes between $500,00-$700,00.  But it's the proliferation of million-plus that starts to skew the "average."

Comment: You're mistaken on even this (personally aimed) point.  

The spiritual life - the interior life with God - isn't so much "tricky" (in it being particularly difficult to figure out) but rather that it's hard, & so it's not taken up in earnest by many people.

They seek the interior life for the wrong reason - for "consolation" or for "good feelings" rather than a more pure motive:

They stop their periods of prayer when it's dry, or "when I don't get something out of it".  

What if Jesus stopped His Crucifixion because "it was difficult" or because "He wasn't getting anything out of it.?

The interior life is quite simple, but it is hard.

But the Church gives many ways to help us build a lively interior life with God:  methods of prayer, great spiritual writing, the life of saints, and of course the incomparable grace handed to us in the Sacraments.

So many helps, so few takers up of the daily cross.   

The gate is, as Our Lord told us, narrow.

Comment: Lynn Willis,
 Re-read the article, it says that the PUBLIC voter lists, sans confidential information is "Routinely provided to political operatives and other groups". Been doing that as far back as in the early 1970's in Alaska. 
Try reading the federal laws regarding the National Voter Registration of 1993 , the Executive Order signed by Bill Clinton in 1994 implementing it, the Voter's Righrs Act, the HAVA of 2002 and the State of Alaska statues for clarification.
The US Department of Justice's web site has a lot of info as they are the folks who enforce the laws over voting and elections.As far as what I can tell, there is nothing in the federal statues that gives voters the right to privacy (other than their confidential information) with a few exceptions that I found under the NVR. If I go to apply for welfare and they ask me if I want to register to vote, and I say NO, that is confidential. If I say yes and they register me, where I registered (welfare office) is confidential.

Comment: "That portion isn’t small or unimportant— it provides an excellent first approximation of many financial markets and circumstances, and should never be ignored— but it’s still incomplete.  Market behavior, like all human behavior, is the outcome of eons of evolutionary forces.

"In fact, investors would be wise to adopt the Efficient Markets Hypothesis as the starting point of any business decision.  Before launching a venture, asking why your particular idea should succeed, and why someone else hasn’t already done it, is a valuable discipline that can save you a lot of time and money.  But the Efficient Markets Hypothesis can only do so much. 

"After all, successful ventures do get launched all the time, so markets can’t really be perfectly efficient, can they?  Otherwise someone else would have already brought the same idea to the market.  That’s the counter-intuitive nature of the Efficient Markets Hypothesis."

This "pass these separate tests for graduation" thing has only been in place for about 10 years in Washington State, if I read the article correctly.  This thing was put in place because of the abysmal graduation rate but it really hasn't gone up much since.

Simply put, Mr. Lundberg's position on this is the epitome of what's wrong with our education system - the graduation numbers are awful and rather than address what's causing that, he wants to remove anything that will hinder graduation without any regard as to what the student is left with afterward.

It doesn't matter what system you use...graduation without meaningful measurement harms the student.

Comment: Three things come to mind here. The first:
1)  There seems to be a view of the Eucharist proposed by some (including perhaps the present pope) that verges on magical thinking:  the notion that the Eucharist is some sort of spiritual vitamin that perks us up--the corollary being that if you don't receive Communion you run the risk of becoming spiritually malnourished.  So it follows that it can only be 'merciful' to open Communion up to the divorced-and-remarried, and indeed (following the logic further) to all comers.
While we can't expect to hammer out a complete Eucharistic theology in a combox, I'd suggest this view is in many ways deficient.  An alternative is one in which the Eucharist encourages us to repent of our sins and reform our lives.  Instead of insisting that the Eucharist be supplied to us, we should move towards personal holiness and thus be bring ourselves closer to the sacrament.

Comment: There are lists I've read for that address and others nearby. These lists are public information. What used, when, and where. The Weekly publishes it too. 

Do they make profits? I guess they do, because they keep on keeping on. But what magic sprays will rescue tree plantations from drought, beetle infestation and conflagration? What potential boondoggle-villes! Profit über alles!

As I've said here before, I've been employed as a tractor driver out in Lorane, and I get plenty of outside time to see what's happening. I've witnessed scotch broom proliferate despite spraying, blackberries too.

 While there may yet be paltry profit to eke out of the squalorous plantations, the golden days of lumbering are over. The mega-corporate outfits are going to further automate and mechanize workers out of jobs without so much as a thought.

The centralized collapsing of the timber industry in the Pacific Northwest is a microcosm of how the prior century of irrational exuberance is now imploding.

Comment: Part 7 (continued from earlier response)

Using the model described in Parts 3 through 6, it is understandable that the Spirit of a loving God -- the same Spirit, the same God -- can encourage different people on their different journeys.  It would appear that the sensible approach is to grant the 'other' credit for honesty and humility, and encourage them on their way.

Ordinary hospitality is probably not an issue.  The challenge is dealing with conceptualizations a) that touch on religious truth and b) that are strongly held by people whose world view does not incorporate the first premise.  The Sunnis and the Shias come to mind, but Christianity has its own history of religious war.

But if the model is adopted, then I see much to be gained from dialogue and mutual support.  Certainly, as between you, brother Kevin, myself ad EFC1127A.

Peace and a blessed Easter to all.

P.S.  I appreciate that the chances of anyone reading this series of posts is somewhere between slim ad none.

Comment: USFWS was going to just list the  plover,  due to a census of 100+- birds on Oregon and Washington coasts.  There were interior birds living on the fringes of alkaline lakes in SE Oregon.  And a more robust population in CA,  a preponderance using the margins of south SF Bay salt evaporation ponds which were scheduled for abandonment.  No hearings,  no public meeting,  just a bureaucratic process in Sacramento.  I petitioned,  as allowed in the law,  to have a hearing at Hatfield Marine Science Center.  From that came the input about Oregon's beach being public, the threats from beach grass and predators,  plus innocent  human depredation with dogs off the leash on breeding beaches.  Recreationists had to be a part of the solution,  with no immunity to being part of the problem.  Now that there are six times the number of birds,  the plover recovery has been a rewarding process for Oregonians.  The beaches are still public and only seasonally restricted for plovers,  on short sections.

Comment: You is the formal form for the second person, Thou is the familiar form. The formal You still replaces the familiar thou in most 2nd person singular usages, so i dont understand what has long ceased. Possibly you meant you had already begun to replace thou? Or maybe that thou was already obsolete in Cranmer's day?
Early Quakers, long after Cranmer, used thou precisely to promote the idea of equality.
For Cranmer, the intent probably was to make God more familiar, less remote. That has changed as we have dropped thou from ordinary speech, making Thou more formal and distancing. The translations are still good, but they are probably not heard in the way Cranmer meant them.

Comment: Stories like this will continue. Individuals in hospital taking a bed when they are "dischargeable" is a HUGE problem in Ontario (ALC beds). What a lot of families are cheesed about is the fact that in a regular hospital they are usually not charged a per diem fee. In a Long-Term Care home, however, residents are charged. One way to deal with this problem is that absolutely everyone who is deemed ALC should be required to pay the per diem fee. Not $1100 per day - which may be what the daily rate is at that particular hospital (i.e., someone without OHIP would be charged this amount). The son needs to suck it up and either pay for 24 hour care for his dad or pay the per diem.
